   - BPs low so continued on norepinephrine, but gtt decreased slightly

   - Attempted A-line but not successful and patient refused further

   Differential-Neuts:94.4 %, Lymph:3.0 %, Mono:2.2 %, Eos:0.3 %, LDH:283
   IU/L, Ca++:9.3 mg/dL, Mg++:2.4 mg/dL, PO4:6.1 mg/dL.
   BNP 6666
   Urine osms
 348; Na 84; Cr 27; BUN 335 at 3pm
   [**4-1**] UA mod leuk, [**5-30**] WBC, few bact, positive eos
   TSH 4.7
   Micro: [**4-1**] Urine cx pending
   [**4-2**] CXR: pending
   [**4-1**] CXR: prelim read - right CVL ends in lower SVC. otherwise little
   change from prior.
   [**4-1**] CXR: Increased right and continued left pleural effusion.
   Assessment and Plan
   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,
   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Pt with dyspnea and hypoxia with evidence of fluid
   overload clinically and on CXR c/w her history of severe and tenuous
   dCHF; BNP 6666. She describes an acute onset which raises concern for
   an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers, cough, or clear
   consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic afib but rate
   controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2 sets CE neg. PE
   possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or hemoptysis; she
   does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as hematoma). Question
   component of reactive airways disease given earlier response to
   albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam currently.
   Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute decompensation.  Per
   daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past week already; there
   may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med compliance in this pt with
   baseline dCHF that has been very difficult to manage. Pt did report
   that she vomited up possibly some of her medications recently.
   - Diuresis currently limited by BP; will try to wean of levophed and
   start lasix gtt for diuresis when able. Pt currently self diuresing
   decently; suspect due to improved BPs on levophed
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Consider repeat [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt reports stable LLE edema; consider bilateral LENIs to r/o DVT -
   would hold off on CTA chest for now given ARF
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] notified of admission; he will stop by today; suggests
   possible need for ultrafiltration
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time. CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; culture pending.
   - Cipro started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI
   - Will try to wean off levophed for now; suboptimal given dCHF
   - Holding diuretics for now given stable respiratory status but will
   need to
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia: Recent admission for anemia; thought to have recurrent
   lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with guaiac positive dark
   stools but stable Hct since last discharge.  Most c/w LGIB again rather
   than UGIB.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] notified
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 (baseline 1.7) Likely decreased
   renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart failure and
   hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found to have urine
   eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due to reports of
   AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually thought more
   likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%
   - Plan for diuresis as above
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] notified; asked for renal consult to see pt this AM, and
   he will follow while in house; consider a course of ultrafiltration
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Does not seem to be in a UC flare, no increase in
   diarrhea, no abdominal cramping
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   # Restless legs.
   - Takes gabapentin at home; will restart tonight.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: No IVF, replete electrolytes, low Na/1L fluid-restricted
   diet
   # Prophylaxis:
   # Access: Peripherals for now, may need CVL/a-line as above
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   Glycemic Control: Insulin SS
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2109-4-1**] 11:20 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: home PPI
   Communication:  Patient.  SW consult for pt coping.
   Code status: Full (discussed with patient). HCPs are daughter [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12133**] and son [**Name (NI) 149**] (currently in Cancun)
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with a history of severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleed. She was admitted to the ICU with acute dyspnea and hypoxia, hypotension on pressors, and evidence of fluid overload clinically and on CXR.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 70 bpm (63-83 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/58 mmHg (70-133/39-77 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 97%
* CVP: 31 mmHg

The patient has a history of leukocytosis, but no evidence of sepsis at this time. She has a mildly inflammatory urine culture and a CXR showing increased right and continued left pleural effusion.

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 12.1 K/uL
* Hct: 28.8%
* Plt: 236 K/uL
* Cr: 2.5 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 109 mg/dL
* BNP: 6666 pg/mL

The patient's medications include:

* Norepinephrine
* Cipro
* Albuterol
* Lasix
* Spironolactone
* Torsemide
* Metolazone
* Nebulizers (prn)
* Zofran (prn)
* Gabapentin
* Asacol
* Insulin sliding scale

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute respiratory failure (ARF)
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Elevated liver enzymes (LFTs)
* Nausea and vomiting
* Restless legs syndrome
* Hypotension
* Leukocytosis
* Mild anemia
* Chronic atrial fibrillation
* Ulcerative colitis
* Recent lower gastrointestinal bleed

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning off norepinephrine and starting diuresis with Lasix
* Transitioning back to home medications (spironolactone, torsemide, and metolazone) as able
* Nebulizers (prn)
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting antibiotics as needed
* Trending liver enzymes and adjusting medications as necessary
* Monitoring for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and adjusting medications as necessary
* Restarting gabapentin for restless legs syndrome
* Continuing insulin sliding scale for glucose control

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: low Na/1L fluid-restricted diet
* Prophylaxis: DVT (pneumoboots), stress ulcer (home PPI)
* Communication: patient, SW consult for pt coping
* Code status: full (discussed with patient)
* Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

   overload clinically and on CXR c/w her history of severe and tenuous
   dCHF; BNP 6666. She describes an acute onset which raises concern for
   an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers, cough, or clear
   consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic afib but rate
   controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2 sets CE neg. PE
   possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or hemoptysis; she
   does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as hematoma). Question
   component of reactive airways disease given earlier response to
   albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam currently.
   Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute decompensation.  Per
   daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past week already; there
   may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med compliance in this pt with
   baseline dCHF that has been very difficult to manage.

   - Will notify Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] of admission
   .

   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this

   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now

   stools but stable Hct since last discharge.  Most c/w LGIB again rather

   - Will make GI aware (followed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**]

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic CHF, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and a recent lower GI bleed. She was admitted to the ICU with acute dyspnea and hypoxia, hypotensive on pressors, and fluid overload. The patient has a history of chronic AFib, but her rate is controlled. She has leukocytosis, but no evidence of sepsis. The patient has a recent lower GI bleed, and her hemoglobin is stable. She has acute renal failure, likely due to decreased renal perfusion in the setting of decompensated heart failure and hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock due to worsening diastolic CHF
	* Tachycardia due to atrial fibrillation
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to fluid overload
	* Pneumonia due to aspiration or secondary to ulcerative colitis
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to decreased renal perfusion
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to ulcerative colitis or lower GI bleed
	* Malnutrition due to limited oral intake and potential gastrointestinal bleeding
5. Hematological Complications:
	* Anemia due to chronic blood loss or acute bleeding
	* Leukocytosis due to infection or inflammatory response
6. Endocrine Complications:
	* Hypoglycemia due to insulin therapy and potential malnutrition
	* Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism due to thyroid dysfunction
7. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis due to bacteremia or pneumonia
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI) due to catheterization
8. Other Complications:
	* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and hypercoagulability
	* Liver dysfunction due to congestive hepatopathy or liver disease

These potential complications highlight the complexity of the patient's condition and the need for close monitoring and management in the ICU.

   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,
   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Pt with dyspnea and hypoxia with evidence of fluid
   overload clinically and on CXR c/w her history of severe and tenuous
   dCHF; BNP 6666. She describes an acute onset which raises concern for
   an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers, cough, or clear
   consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic afib but rate
   controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2 sets CE neg. PE
   possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or hemoptysis; she
   does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as hematoma). Question
   component of reactive airways disease given earlier response to
   albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam currently.
   Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute decompensation.  Per
   daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past week already; there
   may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med compliance in this pt with
   baseline dCHF that has been very difficult to manage.
   - Diuresis currently limited by BP; will try to wean of levophed and
   start lasix gtt for diuresis when able. Pt currently self diuresing
   decently; suspect due to improved BPs on levophed
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Add on TSH
   - Consider repeat [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt reports stable LLE edema; consider bilateral LENIs to r/o DVT -
   would hold off on CTA chest for now given ARF
   - Will notify Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] of admission
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time.
   - Will try to wean off levophed for now; suboptimal given dCHF
   - If pressor dependent, will need CVL for access and a-line for
   monitoring
   - Holding diuretics for now given stable respiratory status but will
   need to
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   - Send U/A, U/cx
   .
   # Hematochezia: Recent admission for anemia; thought to have recurrent
   lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with guaiac positive dark
   stools but stable Hct since last discharge.  Most c/w LGIB again rather
   than UGIB.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Will make GI aware (followed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**]
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 (baseline 1.7) Likely decreased
   renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart failure and
   hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found to have urine
   eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due to reports of
   AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually thought more
   likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - Send U/A, urine lytes, urine eos
   - Plan for diuresis as above
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   - Will notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] of admission
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Does not seem to be in a UC flare, no increase in
   diarrhea, no abdominal cramping
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: No IVF, replete electrolytes, low Na/1L fluid-restricted
   diet
   # Prophylaxis:
   # Access: Peripherals for now, may need CVL/a-line as above
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   Glycemic Control: Insulin SS

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation (AF), ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to acute dyspnea and hypoxia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 70 bpm (63-83 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/58 mmHg (70-133/77 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute (8-19 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 31 mmHg (26-33 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 12.1 K/uL (9.6 K/uL)
* Hematocrit (Hct): 28.8% (26.8%)
* Platelet count: 236 K/uL (281 K/uL)
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.5 mg/dL (2.4 mg/dL)
* Trop-T: 0.01 ng/mL (<0.01 ng/mL)
* Glucose: 109 mg/dL (120 mg/dL)

The patient's medications include:

* Norepinephrine infusion: 0.06 mcg/kg/min (max was 0.1 mcg/kg/min)
* Lasix: started as a diuretic
* Spironolactone, torsemide, and metolazone: to be transitioned back to home as able
* Nebulizers: prn
* Zofran: prn for nausea

The patient's plan includes:

* Diuresis: to be weaned off norepinephrine and started on lasix as able
* Transition back to home medications: spironolactone, torsemide, and metolazone as able
* Nebulizers: prn
* Add-on TSH: to be ordered
* Consider repeat [**Name (NI) **]: to be considered
* Bilateral lower extremity (LE) venous ultrasound (US): to rule out deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Holding diuretics: for now, given stable respiratory status
* Monitoring: to be continued

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: due to worsening heart failure and hypotension
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): due to decreased renal perfusion and hypotension
3. Respiratory failure: due to fluid overload and hypoxia
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: due to ulcerative colitis and recent lower GI bleed
5. Septicemia: due to leukocytosis and potential sepsis
6. Electrolyte imbalance: due to diuresis and potential hypotension
7. Worsening of AF: due to hypotension and potential electrolyte imbalance

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with a history of severe diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation (AF), ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. She was admitted to the ICU due to acute dyspnea and hypoxia, and is currently on pressors for hypotension. The patient has a baseline diastolic CHF, and her current condition is likely related to an inciting event. She has leukocytosis, but no evidence of sepsis or pneumonia. Her respiratory status is stable, and she is responding to albuterol. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 109/58 mmHg, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 31 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension is likely related to worsening diastolic CHF, and she may be at risk for cardiogenic shock.
2. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's BUN and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating decreased renal perfusion.
3. Hepatotoxicity: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may be related to congestive hepatopathy.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and planned outpatient scoping suggest a possible diagnosis of lower GI bleeding.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's leukocytosis and respiratory symptoms raise concern for pneumonia.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's history of chronic leg edema and current symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of DVT.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory symptoms may indicate respiratory failure.
8. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and respiratory symptoms raise concern for sepsis.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue diuresis with lasix gtt when able.
2. Wean off levophed and transition back to home medications as able.
3. Monitor for signs of sepsis and pneumonia.
4. Consider repeat imaging for DVT.
5. Continue monitoring for signs of cardiogenic shock and ARF.
6. Monitor liver enzymes and consider diuresis to manage hepatotoxicity.
7. Consider repeat imaging for GI bleeding.
8. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and consider mechanical ventilation if necessary.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient has severe diastolic heart failure, and the note mentions the possibility of an inciting event leading to acute decompensation. Close monitoring of vital signs and diuresis is crucial to prevent further deterioration.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's BUN and Cr levels are elevated, indicating decreased renal perfusion. Diuresis and fluid management are essential to prevent further kidney damage.
3. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and a mild inflammatory urine analysis (UA). Close monitoring of temperature, WBC count, and urine culture results is necessary to ensure prompt treatment and prevent sepsis.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of lower GI bleeding and is currently experiencing guaiac-positive stools. Monitoring of stool output and Hct levels is crucial to prevent further bleeding.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient has mild respiratory distress, and the note mentions the possibility of reactive airways disease. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation and respiratory status is necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has mild leukocytosis and is receiving diuretics, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances. Close monitoring of electrolyte levels and adjusting diuretic therapy as necessary is crucial.
7. Hepatopathy: The patient has mild AST and Alk phos elevation, indicating possible congestive hepatopathy. Monitoring of LFTs and diuresis is necessary to prevent further liver damage.
8. Nausea and vomiting: The patient is experiencing nausea, which may be related to uremia or other causes. Close monitoring of nausea and vomiting and adjusting antinausea medication as necessary is crucial.
9. Restless legs syndrome: The patient is experiencing restless legs, which may be related to electrolyte imbalances or other underlying conditions. Monitoring of symptoms and adjusting treatment as necessary is crucial.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further complications and promote clinical improvement.

   dCHF; BNP 6666. She describes an acute onset which raises concern for

   controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2 sets CE neg. PE
   possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or hemoptysis; she
   does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as hematoma). Question
   component of reactive airways disease given earlier response to
   albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam currently.
   Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute decompensation.  Per
   daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past week already; there
   may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med compliance in this pt with
   baseline dCHF that has been very difficult to manage. Pt did report
   that she vomited up possibly some of her medications recently.
   - Diuresis currently limited by BP; will try to wean of levophed and
   start lasix gtt for diuresis when able. Pt currently self diuresing
   decently; suspect due to improved BPs on levophed

   .

   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I have summarized the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient, a 63-year-old female, is admitted to the ICU with severe diastolic CHF, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower GI bleed. She presents with acute dyspnea and hypoxia, which is attributed to fluid overload and worsening CHF. The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation, but the rate is currently controlled.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 70 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 31 mmHg

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 12.1 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 28.8%
* Platelet count (Plt): 236 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 100 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.01 ng/mL
* Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): 6666 pg/mL
* Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): 4.7 μIU/mL
* Urine osmolality: 348 mOsm/kg
* Urine sodium: 84 mmol/L
* Urine creatinine: 27 mg/dL
* Urine BUN: 335 mg/dL

The patient has a diagnosis of acute renal failure, likely due to decreased renal perfusion in the setting of decompensated heart failure and hypotension. She also has a history of ulcerative colitis, which may be contributing to her symptoms.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's BNP level is elevated, indicating cardiac strain. If not managed properly, her heart failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory and cardiovascular compromise.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she has a history of AKI on a previous admission. If not managed properly, her kidney function may deteriorate further, leading to increased morbidity and mortality.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is normal, but her respiratory rate is elevated, indicating potential respiratory compromise. If not managed properly, she may develop respiratory failure, which could lead to further cardiovascular compromise.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of lower GI bleed and is currently experiencing guaiac-positive stools. If not managed properly, she may develop further gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and cardiovascular compromise.
5. Infection: The patient has a mild leukocytosis, but no evidence of sepsis at this time. If not managed properly, she may develop an infection, which could lead to further morbidity and mortality.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue diuretic therapy to manage fluid overload and heart failure.
2. Monitor the patient's kidney function closely and consider ultrafiltration if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's respiratory status closely, and consider non-invasive ventilation if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely, and consider further evaluation and management if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's temperature and WBC count closely, and consider further evaluation and management if necessary.

I also recommend that the patient's code status be updated to reflect her current condition and potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old woman with severe diastolic dysfunction, presenting with shortness of breath (SOB) and hypertensive optic neuropathy (HOTN). She has a history of allergies to Lisinopril, Kefzol, Sulfa, and shellfish-derived products. She is currently receiving ICU care for acute on chronic heart failure, diastolic, with severe volume overload. The patient is also experiencing acute on chronic renal failure, urinary tract infection (UTI), and restless legs syndrome.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 63-83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 96/46 mmHg (207/82 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 15 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* SpO2: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation (AF)
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 37 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 12.1-9.6 K/uL
* Platelet count (Plt): 236-281 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.4-2.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.01-<0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 109-120 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.0/26.4/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 32/<0.01/<0.01, ALT/AST: 9/36, Alk Phos/T Bili: 173/0.8, Differential-Neuts: 94.4%, Lymph: 3.0%, Mono: 2.2%, Eos: 0.3%, LDH: 283 IU/L, Ca++: 9.3 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.4 mg/dL, PO4: 6.1 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's severe diastolic dysfunction and volume overload increase the risk of worsening heart failure, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased peripheral resistance, and further volume overload.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's acute on chronic renal failure and volume overload increase the risk of AKI, which can lead to further worsening of renal function, electrolyte imbalances, and increased mortality.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction, failure, and death.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and worsening respiratory function increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and death.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and underlying cardiac disease increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which can lead to decreased cardiac output, increased risk of stroke, and death.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's chronic kidney disease and volume overload increase the risk of electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
7. Skin breakdown: The patient's chronic kidney disease and volume overload increase the risk of skin breakdown, which can lead to skin ulcers, infections, and death.

   Assessment and Plan
   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,
   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Patient with severe diastolic heart failure, severe
   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She describes an acute onset which
   raises concern for an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Question component of reactive airways disease given earlier
   response to albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam
   currently.  Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute
   decompensation.  Per daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past
   week already; there may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med
   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.
   - Repeat TTE unchanged from prior
   - Episode of chest pain on [**4-2**] resolved; EKG unchanged, troponin
   0.01->0.02
   - Ultrafiltration with careful monitoring of I/O and daily weight, with
   fluid goal -1L daily (careful to maintain pressures)
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - maintain levophed as necessary while diuresing
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (cardiology) recs: ultrafiltration or chronic dialysis for
   volume mgt
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time. CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; repeat culture pending.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric 7
   day course
   - will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible; goal MAP > 60
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia/ulcerative colitis: Recent admission for anemia; thought
   to have recurrent lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with
   guaiac positive dark stools but stable Hct since last discharge.
   Hematochezia most c/w LGIB again rather than UGIB. As patient has no
   increase in diarrhea, no abdominal cramping, this does not seem to be a
   UC flare.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now; transfuse for Hgb > 9 per renal recs
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] (GI) notified: agreed with continuing asacol; can call
   formal consult if needed.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 on admission (baseline 1.7)
   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due
   to reports of AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually
   thought more likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%. Repeat FeUN 23%.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] (Renal) notified and will follow while patient is in house
   - Renal recs: ultrafiltration, transfuse to keep Hgb > 9.0
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs; resolving
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension  and pressor
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   # Restless legs.
   - start home gabapentin

   ultrafiltration

   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,
   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Patient with severe diastolic heart failure, severe
   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She describes an acute onset which
   raises concern for an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Question component of reactive airways disease given earlier
   response to albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam
   currently.  Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute
   decompensation.  Per daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past
   week already; there may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med
   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.
   - Repeat TTE unchanged from prior
   - Episode of chest pain on [**4-2**] resolved; EKG unchanged, troponin
   0.01->0.02
   - Ultrafiltration with careful monitoring of I/O and daily weight, with
   fluid goal -1L daily (careful to maintain pressures)
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - maintain levophed as necessary while diuresing
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (cardiology) recs: ultrafiltration or chronic dialysis for
   volume mgt
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time. CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; repeat culture pending.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric 7
   day course
   - will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible; goal MAP > 60
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia/ulcerative colitis: Recent admission for anemia; thought
   to have recurrent lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with
   guaiac positive dark stools but stable Hct since last discharge.
   Hematochezia most c/w LGIB again rather than UGIB. As patient has no
   increase in diarrhea, no abdominal cramping, this does not seem to be a
   UC flare.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now; transfuse for Hgb > 9 per renal recs
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid

   formal consult if needed.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 on admission (baseline 1.7)
   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due
   to reports of AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually
   thought more likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%. Repeat FeUN 23%.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] (Renal) notified and will follow while patient is in house
   - Renal recs: ultrafiltration, transfuse to keep Hgb > 9.0
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs; resolving
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension  and pressor
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now

   - start home gabapentin

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with a history of severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower GI bleed, admitted with acute dyspnea and hypoxia. She has been experiencing worsening symptoms over the past week, with a recent episode of chest pain and elevated troponin levels. The patient is currently receiving treatment for acute renal failure, hypertension, and electrolyte imbalance.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Pulmonary hypertension exacerbation
	* Right ventricular failure
	* Increased risk of arrhythmias
2. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) progression
	* Chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression
	* Electrolyte imbalance
3. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
4. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
	* Malnutrition or electrolyte imbalance due to inadequate nutrition
5. Hematological complications:
	* Anemia or bleeding due to gastrointestinal bleeding or kidney disease
	* Thrombocytopenia or bleeding due to kidney disease or medication
6. Infectious complications:
	* Urinary tract infection (UTI)
	* Sepsis or septic shock
7. Other complications:
	* Dehydration or electrolyte imbalance due to inadequate fluid management
	* Medication side effects or interactions

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's cardiac function closely, including echocardiograms and cardiac enzymes.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and electrolyte imbalance with medications and close monitoring.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely, including creatinine levels and urine output.
4. Continue to manage the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, including nausea and vomiting, with medications and close monitoring.
5. Monitor the patient's hematological parameters, including hemoglobin and platelet counts, closely.
6. Monitor the patient for signs of infection, including fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis.
7. Continue to manage the patient's medication regimen, including antibiotics and diuretics, closely.
8. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide adequate nutrition and hydration.
9. Monitor the patient's mental status and provide psychological support and counseling as needed.
10. Continuously reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,

   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Patient with severe diastolic heart failure, severe
   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She describes an acute onset which
   raises concern for an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Question component of reactive airways disease given earlier
   response to albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam
   currently.  Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute
   decompensation.  Per daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past
   week already; there may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med
   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.
   - lasix gtt and if not sufficient diuresis consider ultrafiltration
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - monitor I/O, daily weights
   - maintain levophed as necessary while diuresing
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Consider repeat TTE
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] notified of admission; he will stop by today; suggests
   possible need for ultrafiltration
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time. CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; culture pending.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI
   - will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia: Recent admission for anemia; thought to have recurrent
   lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with guaiac positive dark
   stools but stable Hct since last discharge.  Most c/w LGIB again rather
   than UGIB.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] notified
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 (baseline 1.7) Likely decreased
   renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart failure and
   hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found to have urine
   eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due to reports of
   AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually thought more
   likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%
   - Plan for diuresis as above
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] notified; asked for renal consult to see pt this AM, and
   he will follow while in house
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension  and pressor
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Does not seem to be in a UC flare, no increase in
   diarrhea, no abdominal cramping
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   # Restless legs.
   - start home gabapentin
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: No IVF, replete electrolytes, low Na/1L fluid-restricted
   diet
   # Access: Peripherals, CVL
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   Glycemic Control: Insulin SS

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleed. She was admitted with acute dyspnea and hypoxia, and is currently receiving treatment for acute respiratory failure, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. She has a history of recurrent lower gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Pulmonary edema due to severe diastolic heart failure
	* Cardiac tamponade due to right ventricular pressure/volume overload
	* Increased risk of arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to pulmonary edema
	* Pneumonia due to aspiration or secondary to immunosuppressive therapy
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury due to decreased renal perfusion
	* Chronic kidney disease due to underlying heart failure and hypertension
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Hematochezia due to recurrent lower gastrointestinal bleeding
	* Malnutrition due to poor oral intake and potential gastrointestinal bleeding
5. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis due to urinary tract infection or other sources
	* Pneumonia due to aspiration or secondary to immunosuppressive therapy
6. Hematological Complications:
	* Anemia due to chronic bleeding and potential bone marrow suppression
	* Thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow suppression or platelet sequestration
7. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance and potential diabetic ketoacidosis
	* Electrolyte imbalance due to diuresis and potential gastrointestinal bleeding

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with a complex medical history, including severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleeding. She was admitted to the ICU with acute dyspnea and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory support: She requires oxygen therapy and is being monitored for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac status: She has atrial fibrillation, and her heart rate is controlled. Her blood pressure is 95/55 mmHg, and she is being treated with norepinephrine for hypotension.
3. Renal status: She has acute renal failure, with a BUN of 100 and a creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL. She is being treated with diuretics and will be monitored for renal function.
4. Hepatic status: She has elevated liver enzymes, with mild AST and alkaline phosphatase elevation. This is likely due to congestive hepatopathy.
5. Gastrointestinal status: She has a history of ulcerative colitis and has experienced recent lower gastrointestinal bleeding. She is being treated with mesalamine and will be monitored for any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological status: She has no significant neurological deficits, but she is experiencing nausea and has been prescribed zofran for symptom control.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypotension may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
2. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further increases in creatinine and BUN levels.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ulcerative colitis and recent lower gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or bleeding.
4. Hepatic complications: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may worsen, leading to further liver damage or failure.
5. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
6. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and recent gastrointestinal bleeding may increase her risk of infection.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Diuresis: The patient will be treated with diuretics to reduce fluid overload and improve cardiac function.
2. Renal function monitoring: The patient's renal function will be closely monitored, and adjustments will be made to her diuretic regimen as necessary.
3. Gastrointestinal monitoring: The patient's gastrointestinal status will be closely monitored, and adjustments will be made to her treatment regimen as necessary.
4. Cardiovascular monitoring: The patient's cardiovascular status will be closely monitored, and adjustments will be made to her treatment regimen as necessary.
5. Respiratory monitoring: The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and adjustments will be made to her treatment regimen as necessary.
6. Infection prevention: The patient will be monitored for signs of infection, and antibiotics will be prescribed if necessary.

The patient's family members, including her daughter and son, have been notified of her admission and will be kept informed of her progress. The patient's code status is full, and she has been discussed with her family.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old woman with a history of ETOH hepatitis, renal failure, and respiratory failure. She was started on CVVH yesterday and has been experiencing hypotension, requiring levophed. She has also developed bradycardia, which was initially treated but has since resolved. Her FiO2 was weaned, and she has been about 100cc negative per hour.

The patient has a number of comorbidities, including cirrhosis of the liver, chronic kidney disease, and heart failure. She has also developed a candidal urinary tract infection, which requires treatment.

The patient's laboratory results indicate that she has abnormal liver function tests, including elevated ALT and AST levels. Her kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 6.9 mg/dL. Her blood glucose level is elevated at 129 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination reveals jaundice, ascites, and peripheral edema. Her heart rhythm is junctional, and her blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Hepatorenal syndrome: The patient's liver dysfunction and kidney failure increase her risk of developing hepatorenal syndrome, a condition characterized by rapid deterioration of kidney function in patients with liver disease.
2. Sepsis: The patient's candidal urinary tract infection and other comorbidities increase her risk of developing sepsis, a life-threatening condition characterized by a systemic inflammatory response to infection.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation increase her risk of developing respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications such as pneumonia and lung damage.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's heart failure and chronic kidney disease increase her risk of developing cardiac failure, which can lead to further complications such as cardiogenic shock and arrhythmias.
5. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and comorbidities increase her risk of developing infections, which can be life-threatening.

In terms of treatment, the patient is receiving CVVH, which is helping to remove fluid and improve her renal function. She is also receiving antibiotics for her candidal urinary tract infection and other comorbidities. Further treatment will depend on the patient's response to therapy and the development of any new complications.

   63 yo female with severe diastolic CHF, pulm HTN, afib, ulcerative
   colitis, and recent lower GI bleed p/w acute dyspnea and hypoxia,
   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Patient with severe diastolic heart failure, severe
   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She describes an acute onset which
   raises concern for an inciting event. Pt w/ leukocytosis but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Question component of reactive airways disease given earlier
   response to albuterol although no h/o COPD and no wheezes on exam
   currently.  Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute
   decompensation.  Per daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past
   week already; there may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med
   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.
   - Repeat TTE unchanged from prior
   - Episode of chest pain on [**4-2**] resolved; EKG unchanged, troponin
   0.01->0.02
   - Ultrafiltration with careful monitoring of I/O and daily weight, with
   fluid goal -1L daily (careful to maintain pressures)
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - maintain levophed as necessary while diuresing
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (cardiology) recs: ultrafiltration or chronic dialysis for
   volume mgt
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis but no evidence of sepsis at this
   time. CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; repeat culture pending.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric 7
   day course
   - will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible; goal MAP > 60
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia/ulcerative colitis: Recent admission for anemia; thought
   to have recurrent lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with
   guaiac positive dark stools but stable Hct since last discharge.
   Hematochezia most c/w LGIB again rather than UGIB. As patient has no
   increase in diarrhea, no abdominal cramping, this does not seem to be a
   UC flare.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now; transfuse for Hgb > 9 per renal recs
 will
   transfuse one unit today and get post transfusion hematocrit.
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] (GI) notified: agreed with continuing asacol; can call
   formal consult if needed.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 on admission (baseline 1.7)
   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due
   to reports of AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually
   thought more likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%. Repeat FeUN 23%.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] (Renal) notified and will follow while patient is in house
   - Renal recs: ultrafiltration, transfuse to keep Hgb > 9.0
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs; resolving
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension  and pressor
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   # Restless legs.
   -          start home gabapentin
   # LLE Abscess
 does not appear to be an abscess/cellulites, but can
   attempt to I&D today with scalpel versus needle aspirate.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Replete electrolytes, low Na/1L fluid-restricted diet,
   ultrafiltration
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

   # Hematochezia/ulcerative colitis: Recent admission for anemia; thought
   to have recurrent lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with
   guaiac positive dark stools but stable Hct since last discharge.
   Hematochezia most c/w LGIB again rather than UGIB. As patient has no
   increase in diarrhea, no abdominal cramping, this does not seem to be a
   UC flare.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now; transfuse for Hgb > 9 per renal recs
 will
   transfuse one unit today and get post transfusion hematocrit.
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] (GI) notified: agreed with continuing asacol; can call
   formal consult if needed.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 on admission (baseline 1.7)
   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due
   to reports of AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually
   thought more likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%. Repeat FeUN 23%.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] (Renal) notified and will follow while patient is in house
   - Renal recs: ultrafiltration, transfuse to keep Hgb > 9.0
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs; resolving
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - hold metoprolol for now in setting of hypotension  and pressor
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale for now
   # Restless legs.
   -          start home gabapentin
   # LLE Abscess
 does not appear to be an abscess/cellulites, but can
   attempt to I&D today with scalpel versus needle aspirate.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Replete electrolytes, low Na/1L fluid-restricted diet,
   ultrafiltration
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   Glycemic Control: Insulin SS

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleeding. She was admitted to the ICU with acute dyspnea and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She has a respiratory rate of 9 inspirations per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.
* Cardiovascular: She has a heart rate of 59 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 95/55 mmHg. She is receiving norepinephrine to support her blood pressure.
* Renal: Her creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen is 100 mg/dL. She has acute renal failure and is receiving ultrafiltration to manage her volume status.
* Gastrointestinal: She has guaiac-positive stools and is receiving ciprofloxacin for empiric treatment of urinary tract infection. She is also receiving metolazone to manage her edema.
* Hematology: Her hemoglobin is 7.0 g/dL, and her platelet count is 212,000/μL.
* Neurological: She has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac: Her severe diastolic heart failure and pulmonary hypertension may lead to further decompensation and worsening of her condition.
* Renal: Her acute renal failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential kidney damage.
* Gastrointestinal: Her ulcerative colitis may flare up if not managed properly, leading to further gastrointestinal bleeding and potential complications.
* Infection: Her urinary tract infection may worsen if not treated properly, leading to further complications and potential sepsis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Cardiovascular: Continue norepinephrine to support her blood pressure and ultrafiltration to manage her volume status.
* Renal: Continue ultrafiltration and consider chronic dialysis if her renal function does not improve.
* Gastrointestinal: Continue ciprofloxacin for empiric treatment of urinary tract infection and metolazone to manage her edema.
* Hematology: Monitor her hemoglobin and platelet count closely and transfuse as needed.
* Neurological: Monitor her neurological status closely and consider further evaluation if necessary.

The patient's code status is full, and her HCPs are her daughter and son. She is currently in the ICU pending clinical improvement.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old woman with severe diastolic chronic heart failure (CHF) and renal failure. She was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.8°C (96.4°F)
* Heart rate: 62 bpm
* Blood pressure: 112/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient has a history of allergies to Lisinopril, Kefzol, Sulfa, and shellfish-derived products. She has been receiving various medications, including Norepinephrine, Calcium Gluconate, and KCl, as part of her CRRT treatment.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, with a right and left radial pulse not assessed
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds with bibasilar crackles
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, and bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema 3+, left lower extremity edema 3+
* Skin: Warm, with fluctuant fluid in the right lower extremity
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 12.1 K/uL
* Platelet count: 212 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.01
* TCO2: 28
* Glucose: 109 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.6/27.5/1.2, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 30/3/0.02, ALT/AST: 11/34, Alk Phos/T Bili: 153/0.6

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Renal failure: Continue CVVH with a goal of 100cc per hour negative
* Heart failure: Continue levophed and monitor for any changes in the patient's condition
* Anemia: Transfuse 1 unit of blood
* Hematochezia: Stable ulcerative colitis and colonic ectasias
* Low sodium diet: Continue to monitor the patient's sodium levels
* Can needle aspirate fluctuant area and culture

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's anemia and platelet count
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic heart failure and respiratory distress
* Infection due to the patient's fluctuant fluid and potential bacteremia
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and electrolyte imbalances
* Renal failure worsening due to the patient's chronic kidney disease and CVVH treatment
* Electrolyte imbalances due to the patient's chronic kidney disease and CVVH treatment

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure her optimal care.

   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She was 87.6kg on admission and up
   to 91kg during admission, up from dry weight of 140-145 lbs (65 kg).
   She describes an acute onset which raises concern for an inciting
   event. Pt w/ leukocytosis at presentation (now resolved) but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and a recent lower gastrointestinal bleed. She was admitted to the ICU for acute dyspnea and hypoxia, and is currently on pressor support with levophed. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C, heart rate of 73 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 106/61 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 95%, and she is on room air.

The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, and her recent admission was complicated by an acute onset of dyspnea and hypoxia. She was found to have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20-30%, and her cardiac index was 1.9 L/min/m². She also has a history of chronic kidney disease, and her creatinine level is 1.9 mg/dL.

The patient's laboratory results show mild leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 6.7 x 10⁹/L. Her hemoglobin level is 7.8 g/dL, and her hematocrit is 23.0%. Her platelet count is 212 x 10⁹/L, and her blood urea nitrogen level is 100 mg/dL.

The patient's medications include ciprofloxacin for empiric treatment of urinary tract infection, levophed for pressor support, and metoprolol for heart failure. She is also taking home medications including spironolactone, torsemide, and metolazone for heart failure, and asacol for ulcerative colitis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's severe diastolic heart failure and pulmonary hypertension increase her risk of cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease increase her risk of renal complications, including acute renal failure, chronic kidney disease progression, and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of ulcerative colitis and recent lower gastrointestinal bleed increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, including bleeding, perforation, and stricture formation.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's urinary tract infection and potential sepsis increase her risk of infectious complications, including bacteremia, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease increase her risk of metabolic complications, including hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia.
6. Pulmonary complications: The patient's chronic pulmonary hypertension and acute respiratory distress syndrome increase her risk of pulmonary complications, including respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and potential electrolyte imbalances increase her risk of neurological complications, including seizures, stroke, and transient ischemic attacks.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust her medications as necessary.
2. Continue to manage her acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease with ultrafiltration and renally adjusted medications.
3. Continue to monitor her gastrointestinal symptoms and adjust her medications as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor her infectious risk and adjust her antibiotics as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor her metabolic function and adjust her medications as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor her pulmonary function and adjust her oxygen therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor her neurological function and adjust her medications as necessary.

   hypotensive on pressors who was transferred from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Patient with severe diastolic heart failure, severe
   TR admitted with dyspnea, hypoxia. She was 87.6kg on admission and up
   to 91kg during admission, up from dry weight of 140-145 lbs (65 kg).
   She describes an acute onset which raises concern for an inciting
   event. Pt w/ leukocytosis at presentation (now resolved) but no fevers,
   cough, or clear consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.  Pt in chronic
   afib but rate controlled.  No CP to suggest ACS; EKG baseline and 2
   sets CE neg. PE possible but no CP, tachycardia (on beta blocker), or
   hemoptysis; she does have chronic LLE edema, now ?L>R (same leg as
   hematoma). Thyroid dysfunction unlikely to provoke acute
   decompensation.  Per daughter, sx may have been worsening over the past
   week already; there may be a component of suboptimal dietary/med
   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.
   - Repeat TTE unchanged from prior
   - Episode of chest pain on [**4-2**] resolved; EKG unchanged, troponin
   0.01->0.02
   - Ultrafiltration with careful monitoring of I/O and daily weight ([**4-4**]
   was 85kg), with fluid goal -1 to -2 L daily (careful to maintain
   pressures)
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - Maintain levophed as necessary while diuresing (weaned off on [**4-4**])
   - Will transition back to home spironolactone, torsemide, and
   metolazone as able
   - Nebulizers prn
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (cardiology) recs: ultrafiltration and/or chronic dialysis
   for volume mgt
   .
   # Hypotension: Most likely cardiogenic in setting of worsening dCHF. Pt
   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis (resolved) but no evidence of sepsis.
   CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; repeat culture with GNRs >100K.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric 7
   day course
   - Will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible; goal MAP > 60
   - Monitor temp curve, WBC for now
   .
   # Hematochezia/ulcerative colitis: Recent admission for anemia; thought
   to have recurrent lower GI angioectasia bleeding.  Pt currently with
   guaiac positive dark stools but stable Hct since last discharge.
   Hematochezia most c/w LGIB again rather than UGIB. As patient has no
   increase in diarrhea, no abdominal cramping, this does not seem to be a
   UC flare.
   - Active T&S
   - Trend Hct [**Hospital1 **] for now; transfuse for Hgb > 9 per renal recs (received
   one unit on [**4-3**] without appropriate bump; will transfuse another unit
   today [**4-4**] and check post-transfusion Hct)
   - Cont home po PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Continue asacol 800mg tid
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 6753**] (GI) notified: agreed with continuing asacol; can call
   formal consult if needed.
   - Pt with diarrhea since starting ciprofloxacin, likely related to
   antibiotic rather than acute UC flare. Will follow; check C. Diff if
   continues.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: BUN 100, Cr 2.5 on admission (baseline 1.7)
   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due
   to reports of AIN with this but restarted when stabilized; eventually
   thought more likely from prerenal azotemia.
   - FeNA = 5.8%, FeUN = 31%. Repeat FeUN 23%.
   - Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1948**] (Renal) notified and will follow while patient is in house
   - Renal recs: ultrafiltration, transfuse to keep Hgb > 9.0
   - Trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Mild AST and Alk phos elevation; nl ALT and Tbili. No
   abd pain. Likely congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend LFTs; resolving
   - Diuresis as above
   .
   # Nausea: [**Month (only) 60**] be related to uremia.  No evidence of gastroenteritis
   currently; abd benign.
   - Zofran prn
   - Monitor for now
   .
   # Afib: Stable with slow ventricular response; not anticoagulated
   secondary to GI bleeding
   - Can restart metoprolol when pressures stabilized and off CVVH
   .
   # H/o DM: Not on hypoglycemics.
   - Insulin sliding scale
   # Pain. Pt reports diffuse pain in legs, arms,
everywhere but my
   stomach
   - continue home gabapentin; bengay also ordered
   - Continue pt
s oxycodone
   # UTI: Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric
   7 day course. Follow-up culture results.
   # LLE fluctuant mass
 most likely hematoma, as documented in previous

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleed, admitted to the ICU with acute dyspnea and hypoxia. The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation, but the current episode is rate-controlled. The patient has a chronic lower extremity edema, which is worsening.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.9°C (96.7°F)
* Heart rate: 73 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 106/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 23.0%
* White blood cell count: 6.7 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 212 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 100 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 142 mEq/L, K 5.3 mEq/L, Cl 118 mg/dL, HCO3 25 mEq/L

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Cardiovascular: irregularly irregular rhythm, normal rate
* Pulmonary: CTAB anteriorly, significantly decreased BS at bases, no crackles
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, BS+
* Extremities: 4+ pitting edema bilaterally in LE; left shin with fluctuant hematoma unchanged from yesterday

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Severe diastolic heart failure
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Atrial fibrillation
* Ulcerative colitis
* Recent lower gastrointestinal bleed
* Chronic lower extremity edema
* Acute renal failure
* Elevated liver function tests (LFTs)
* Nausea and vomiting
* Anxiety and depression

The patient's plan includes:

* Ultrafiltration with careful monitoring of I/O and daily weight
* Diuresis with furosemide and metolazone
* Transfusion of packed red blood cells to maintain hemoglobin > 9.0 g/dL
* Monitoring of electrolytes and liver function tests
* Ciprofloxacin for empiric treatment of urinary tract infection (UTI)
* Zofran for nausea and vomiting
* Gabapentin and oxycodone for pain management
* Insulin sliding scale for blood glucose control
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac complications: worsening heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest
* Pulmonary complications: respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Gastrointestinal complications: gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and sepsis
* Renal complications: acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalance
* Liver complications: worsening liver function, jaundice, and hepatic encephalopathy
* Infection: UTI, pneumonia, and sepsis
* Thrombotic complications: DVT, pulmonary embolism, and stroke

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   compliance in this pt with baseline dCHF that has been very difficult
   to manage.

   fluid goal -1 to -2 L daily (careful to maintain pressures)

   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] (cardiology) recs: ultrafiltration and/or chronic dialysis
   for volume mgt

   does have known colitis with guaiac positive stools and planned for
   outpatient scoping; stable Hct suggests that this is more a slow
   bleed.  Pt with mild leukocytosis (resolved) but no evidence of sepsis.
   CVL placed. UA mildly inflammatory; repeat culture with GNRs >100K.
   - Ciprofloxacin started [**4-1**] for empiric treatment of UTI, empiric 7
   day course
   - Will maintain levophed for pressor support in setting of aggressive
   diuresis and attempt to wean as possible; goal MAP > 60

   Likely decreased renal perfusion in setting of decompensated heart
   failure and hypotension. Did have ARF on last admission and was found
   to have urine eos on last admission and mesalamine initially held due

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with severe diastolic heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, ulcerative colitis, and recent lower gastrointestinal bleed. She was admitted with acute dyspnea and hypoxia, and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for management.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Leukocytosis at presentation, which has resolved
* Mild elevation in AST and alkaline phosphatase, likely due to congestive hepatopathy
* Elevated BUN and creatinine, indicating acute renal failure
* Stable hemoglobin and hematocrit
* Mild elevation in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
* Normal calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.9°C (96.7°F)
* Heart rate: 73 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 106/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Central venous pressure: 25 mmHg

The patient's medical history includes:

* Severe diastolic heart failure
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Atrial fibrillation
* Ulcerative colitis
* Recent lower gastrointestinal bleed
* Acute renal failure
* Elevated liver enzymes
* Mild leukocytosis
* Mild elevation in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

The patient's medications include:

* Spironolactone
* Torsemide
* Metolazone
* Nebulizers (as needed)
* Ciprofloxacin (started for empiric treatment of urinary tract infection)
* Levophed (for pressor support)
* Zofran (for nausea)
* Insulin sliding scale
* Gabapentin (for restless legs)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock
* Pulmonary edema
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Liver failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Infection

The patient's code status is full, and she has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) order. Her disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.
